questions.stem: Which detail is most important to include in attendance notes in custody?

options.text: Your personal opinion of the investigating officer
Key times, decisions, advice given, and the client’s instructions
Only the final outcome
Only what the client says, with no context

questions.explanation: Good notes are structured and factual. Times and reasons matter (e.g., legal advice request, disclosure, interview start/finish, breaks, key representations).

references.cite: Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — record keeping

questions.stem: Which note style is most defensible professionally?

options.text: Speculative: 'Police definitely lying'
Factual: 'Client states X; disclosure states Y; advice given; instruction taken'
Minimal: 'Seen at station'
Humorous: 'All a mess lol'

questions.explanation: Factual, contemporaneous notes that clearly separate what was said by whom, what was disclosed, what advice you gave, and what instructions you received are most defensible.

references.cite: Professional record keeping: objective note taking (Check: guidance)
Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — record keeping

questions.stem: Which is the best example of a reflective learning point?

options.text: “Police were unfair.”
“Next time, I will request targeted disclosure earlier and record limits in the custody record/notes.”
“Client was difficult.”
“I did everything perfectly.”

questions.explanation: Reflection should be specific, actionable, and linked to practice improvement—not blame or vague judgments.

references.cite: SRA PSRAS Assessment Guidelines — reflective practice

questions.stem: Why is it important to record 'what you would do differently' in a reflection?

options.text: It proves you are not confident
It shows insight and continuous improvement, supporting competence evidence
It allows you to change the client’s instructions later
It guarantees better grades

questions.explanation: Reflective evidence is strongest when it shows analysis and improvement plans. It demonstrates learning rather than just recounting events.

questions.stem: A good attendance note should make it easy for a third party to understand which of these?

options.text: Your favourite legal book
The timeline, disclosure received, advice given, and key decisions/reasons
The client’s private thoughts unrelated to the case
How you felt about the officer’s tone

questions.explanation: Third-party readability is a good quality test: clear timeline, objective facts, advice and instructions, and key representations.

references.cite: Attendance note quality and audit expectations (Check: guidance)
Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — record keeping

questions.stem: Which reflection is most likely to be useful for skill development?

options.text: “Nothing to learn — it was routine.”
“I identified a vulnerability late; next time I will screen earlier and request safeguards before interview.”
“Police always do this.”
“Client should have listened.”

questions.explanation: High-quality reflection identifies a specific gap, why it mattered, and an actionable improvement plan.

references.cite: Reflective practice: identify improvement actions (Check: guidance)
Code C para 1.4 and Annex E (definition of vulnerable person)

questions.stem: Which is a common pitfall in attendance note writing?

options.text: Writing down key times
Mixing speculation/opinion with facts without clear separation
Recording advice and instructions
Using headings for structure

questions.explanation: Notes should distinguish facts, client instructions, disclosure, and professional opinion. If you include an opinion, label it clearly and keep it professional.

references.cite: Objective note taking: separate fact from opinion (Check: guidance)
Police Station Register Arrangements 2025 — record keeping

questions.stem: Which is most appropriate to include in a training portfolio reflection?

options.text: Client-identifying names and addresses to prove authenticity
Generic, anonymised descriptions focused on learning and process
Screenshots of private messages
Personal gossip about custody staff

questions.explanation: Portfolio evidence should protect confidentiality and focus on professional learning. Do not include identifying information.

references.cite: Confidentiality and anonymisation in portfolio evidence (Check: guidance)
